elements.content: Extended tapes of cyclic water hexamers are formed in a one-dimensional copper(II) complex bridged by oxalate with a rare mono, bidentate coordination mode. The water tapes are stabilized by the hydrogen bond interactions between uncoordinated oxalate oxygen atoms and water molecules. Magnetic analysis reveals weak ferromagnetic interactions mediated by the oxalate bridge with the exchange parameter J = 0.36 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: Extended tapes of cyclic water hexamers are formed in a one-dimensional copper(II) complex bridged by oxalate with a rare mono, bidentate coordination mode. The water tapes are stabilized by the hydrogen bond interactions between uncoordinated oxalate oxygen atoms and water molecules. Magnetic analysis reveals weak ferromagnetic interactions mediated by the oxalate bridge with the exchange parameter J = 0.36 cm-1.

elements.content: Extended tapes of cyclic water hexamers are embedded in a one-dimensional copper(II) complex bridged by oxalate with an unusual coordination mode. The water tapes are stabilized by water−oxalate and water−water interactions. The weak ferromagnetic interactions occur between copper ions linked by the oxalate anions.
elements.clean_text: Extended tapes of cyclic water hexamers are embedded in a one-dimensional copper(II) complex bridged by oxalate with an unusual coordination mode. The water tapes are stabilized by water-oxalate and water-water interactions. The weak ferromagnetic interactions occur between copper ions linked by the oxalate anions.

elements.content: Water has raised more interest than other compounds because of its fundamental importance in many biological and chemical processes. In this context, water clusters have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally, because they can provide a description and insights into the structures and characteristics of liquid water or ice. A variety of water clusters such as trimers, tetramers, pentamers, and larger oligomers have been investigated. Among those, hexamer water clusters are more interesting. Recent studies indicate that this cluster is the smallest possible unit that can exhibit some of the properties found in bulk water. However, on the basis of how the discrete water clusters form chains, tapes, and layers and how they are stabilized in crystal hosts, much work is required to synthesize new species with some special frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Water has raised more interest than other compounds because of its fundamental importance in many biological and chemical processes. In this context, water clusters have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally, because they can provide a description and insights into the structures and characteristics of liquid water or ice. A variety of water clusters such as trimers, tetramers, pentamers, and larger oligomers have been investigated. Among those, hexamer water clusters are more interesting. Recent studies indicate that this cluster is the smallest possible unit that can exhibit some of the properties found in bulk water. However, on the basis of how the discrete water clusters form chains, tapes, and layers and how they are stabilized in crystal hosts, much work is required to synthesize new species with some special frameworks.

elements.content: On the other hand, the oxalate ligand as old but evergreen bridging ligand has played a key role in the field of molecular magnetism because of its remarkable ability to mediate magnetic exchange interactions between transition metal centers. By employing this ligand, a great diversity of homo- and heterometallic compounds with interesting structures (one-, two-, and three-dimensional) and physical properties have been prepared. In general, the adoption of the bis(chelating) coordination mode of the oxalate bridge to form five-membered rings with the metal centers is extensively dominant, and so far the number of compounds structurally characterized in which one or two oxygen atoms of the oxalate are uncoordinated is very rare. The magnetostructural studies on this kind of oxalato-bridged metal complexes are limited.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the oxalate ligand as old but evergreen bridging ligand has played a key role in the field of molecular magnetism because of its remarkable ability to mediate magnetic exchange interactions between transition metal centers. By employing this ligand, a great diversity of homo- and heterometallic compounds with interesting structures (one-, two-, and three-dimensional) and physical properties have been prepared. In general, the adoption of the bis(chelating) coordination mode of the oxalate bridge to form five-membered rings with the metal centers is extensively dominant, and so far the number of compounds structurally characterized in which one or two oxygen atoms of the oxalate are uncoordinated is very rare. The magnetostructural studies on this kind of oxalato-bridged metal complexes are limited.

elements.content: Herein, we report a ferromagnetic one-dimensional oxalate-bridged copper(II) complex [Cu(L)(ox)] n ·3nH2O(1), (L = bidentate Schiff base ligand; ox = oxalate anion), in which the oxalate ligands bridge the metal ions through an unusual mono, bidentate coordination mode. Cyclic water hexamers with chair conformation self-assemble into unprecedented one-dimensional tapes, which are stabilized by uncoordinated oxalate oxygen atoms because of the hydrogen bond interactions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a ferromagnetic one-dimensional oxalate-bridged copper(II) complex [Cu(L)(ox)] n ⋅3nH2O(1), (L = bidentate Schiff base ligand; ox = oxalate anion), in which the oxalate ligands bridge the metal ions through an unusual mono, bidentate coordination mode. Cyclic water hexamers with chair conformation self-assemble into unprecedented one-dimensional tapes, which are stabilized by uncoordinated oxalate oxygen atoms because of the hydrogen bond interactions.

elements.content: Deep green crystals of 1 were obtained by slow evaporation of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, [(NH4)3Fe(ox)3)]·3H2O, and L in water/methanol for 1 month. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 is built of [Cu(L)]2+ units bridged by oxalate anions to form zigzag chains parallel to the a-axis (Figure ). The Cu(II) ion is pentacoordinate, by virtue of two oxygen atoms (Cu(1)−O(1), 1.964(3) Å; Cu(1)−O(2), 1.951(3) Å) from one oxalate ligand and two nitrogen atoms (Cu(1)−N(1), 2.031(4)Å; Cu(1)−N(2), 1.998(4)Å) of bidentate Schiff base ligand to form the basal plane and the coordination sphere is completed by an apical oxygen atom from another oxalate with a longer bond (Cu(1)−O(4A), 2.325(3) Å). The coordination geometry at the copper center can be described as slightly distorted square pyramid with a parameter τ = 0.1[τ = |β − α|/60, where β and α are the bond angles involving the trans donor atoms in the basal plane, τ = 0 and 1 for ideal square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometries, respectively. The shortest intrachain copper−copper distance across the oxalate ligand is 6.003 Å, which is longer than those polynuclear complexes with bis-bidentate oxalate bridges (<5.8 Å). The oxalate ligand is not planar and the two −CO2 entities are twisted 7° with respect to each other around the C−C bond. There exist π−π interactions between the aromatic rings of the Schiff base ligands of the adjacent chains (offset face to face distance 3.7 Å), which induce adjacent chains in a 2D layered structure (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Deep green crystals of 1 were obtained by slow evaporation of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, [(NH4)3Fe(ox)3)]⋅3H2O, and L in water/methanol for 1 month. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 is built of [Cu(L)]2+ units bridged by oxalate anions to form zigzag chains parallel to the a-axis (Figure ). The Cu(II) ion is pentacoordinate, by virtue of two oxygen atoms (Cu(1)-O(1), 1.964(3) Å; Cu(1)-O(2), 1.951(3) Å) from one oxalate ligand and two nitrogen atoms (Cu(1)-N(1), 2.031(4)Å; Cu(1)-N(2), 1.998(4)Å) of bidentate Schiff base ligand to form the basal plane and the coordination sphere is completed by an apical oxygen atom from another oxalate with a longer bond (Cu(1)-O(4A), 2.325(3)  Å). The coordination geometry at the copper center can be described as slightly distorted square pyramid with a parameter τ = 0.1[τ = |β - α|/60, where β and α are the bond angles involving the trans donor atoms in the basal plane, τ = 0 and 1 for ideal square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometries, respectively. The shortest intrachain copper-copper distance across the oxalate ligand is 6.003 Å, which is longer than those polynuclear complexes with bis-bidentate oxalate bridges (<5.8 Å). The oxalate ligand is not planar and the two -CO2 entities are twisted 7° with respect to each other around the C-C bond. There exist π-π interactions between the aromatic rings of the Schiff base ligands of the adjacent chains (offset face to face distance 3.7 Å), which induce adjacent chains in a 2D layered structure (Figure ).

elements.content: 1D chains locked through π−π interactions between adjacent chains in complex1.
elements.clean_text: 2  1D chains locked through π-π interactions between adjacent chains in complex1.

elements.content: Interestingly, the water molecules, which are associated by O−H···O hydrogen bonds into cyclic centrosymmetric hexamers, adopt an icelike chair conformation (Figure a); geometric parameters of the hexamers are summarized in Table . The average O−O−O angles is 111° (O(8B)−O(6A)−O(7C), 102°; O(6A)−O(7C)−O(8D), 129°; O(7C)−O(8D)−O(6E), 104°) (symmetry codes:  A x − 1, y, z; B −x, −1/2 + y, −z + 1/2; C −x, −y + 1, −z + 1; D x, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2; E −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1). For comparison, the corresponding value in ice Ih is 109.3° at −90 °C. There is a wide variation in the average O···O distance due to the weak O(6A)−H···O(8B) (3.342 Å, A x − 1, y, z; B −x, −1/2 + y, −z + 1/2) hydrogen bonds caused by strong O(7)−H···O(8BB) (2.883 Å, BB x, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2) and O(8B)−H···O(3B) (2.845 Å, B −x, −1/2 + y, −z + 1/2) hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, the hexamers self-assemble by O(7)−H···O(8BB) hydrogen bonds into extended tapes consisting of fused four- and six-membered water rings (Figure b). The interhexamer O···O distance of 2.883 Å is comparable to the O···O distance of 2.85 Å in liquid water. Each extended tape associates two metal−organic chains by O−H···O(2.845 Å) hydrogen bonds between water molecules O(8) and an uncoordinated oxygen atom O(3) of oxalate (Figure ). Here, both water−oxalate and water−water interactions are important for the stability of the overall structure.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the water molecules, which are associated by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds into cyclic centrosymmetric hexamers, adopt an icelike chair conformation (Figure a); geometric parameters of the hexamers are summarized in Table . The average O-O-O angles is 111° (O(8B)-O(6A)-O(7C), 102°; O(6A)-O(7C)-O(8D), 129°; O(7C)-O(8D)-O(6E), 104°) (symmetry codes: A x - 1, y, z; B -x, -1/2 + y, -z + 1/2; C -x, -y + 1, -z + 1; D x, -y + 3/2, z + 1/2; E -x + 1, -y + 1, -z + 1). For comparison, the corresponding value in ice Ih is 109.3° at -90 °C. There is a wide variation in the average O⋅⋅⋅O distance due to the weak O(6A)-H⋅⋅⋅O(8B) (3.342 Å, A x - 1, y, z; B -x, -1/2 + y, -z + 1/2) hydrogen bonds caused by strong O(7)-H⋅⋅⋅O(8BB) (2.883 Å, BB x, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2) and O(8B)-H⋅⋅⋅O(3B) (2.845 Å, B -x, -1/2 + y, -z + 1/2) hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, the hexamers self-assemble by O(7)-H⋅⋅⋅O(8BB) hydrogen bonds into extended tapes consisting of fused four- and six-membered water rings (Figure b). The interhexamer O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.883 Å is comparable to the O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.85 Å in liquid water. Each extended tape associates two metal-organic chains by O-H⋅⋅⋅O(2.845 Å) hydrogen bonds between water molecules O(8) and an uncoordinated oxygen atom O(3) of oxalate (Figure ). Here, both water-oxalate and water-water interactions are important for the stability of the overall structure.

elements.content:
Geometrical Parameters of Hydrogen Bonds (Å, deg) in Complex1 a

D−H···A D···A ∠D−H−A O(8)−H(8‘ ‘)···O(3) 2.845 127.98 O(8)−H(8‘)···O(7)#1 2.874 113 O(7)−H(7‘)···O(6)#2 2.843 170.78 O(7)−H(7‘ ‘)···O(8)#3 2.883 119.56 O(6)−H(6‘)···O(8)#4 3.342 143.12

a  Symmetry codes:  #1 −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #2 −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1; #3 x, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; #4 −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2.

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities for complex 1 were measured in the temperature range 2−300 K at a constant magnetic field of 2 kOe. The temperature dependences of χT are given in Figure . At room temperature, the value of χT is equal to 0.44 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly larger than spin-only value (0.375 cm3 K mol-1) expected for a single uncoupled Cu(II) ion assuming g = 2.0. The χT value increases slowly upon cooling, reaching a value of 0.52 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K, Such magnetic behavior is characteristic of ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers. The magnetic data of 1 were analyzed by Baker's linear chain model. The Hamiltonian is where J is the intrachain-exchange coupling constant, the numerical expression where A = 1.0 + 5.7979916x + 16.902653x 2 + 29.376885x 3 +29.832959x 4 + 14.036918x 5, B = 1.0 + 2.7979916x +7.0086780x 2 + 8.6538644x 3 + 4.5743114x 4, and x = J/2kT. A molecular field (zJ‘), representing a magnetic interaction between chains through π−π interactions and hydrogen bonds, was added to account for the actual nature of the complex. The magnetic data were fitted to lead to g = 2.15, J = 0.36 cm-1, zJ‘ = −0.05 cm-1, and R = 1.39 × 10-4 (the R value is defined as ∑[(χM)obs − (χM)calcd]2/∑[(χM)obs]2).

The χT value increases slowly upon cooling, reaching a value of 0.52 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K, Such magnetic behavior is characteristic of ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers. The magnetic data of 1 were analyzed by Baker's linear chain model. The Hamiltonian is    where J is the intrachain-exchange coupling constant, the numerical expression     where A = 1.0 + 5.7979916x + 16.902653x 2 + 29.376885x 3 +29.832959x 4 + 14.036918x 5, B = 1.0 + 2.7979916x +7.0086780x 2 + 8.6538644x 3 + 4.5743114x 4, and x = J/2kT. A molecular field (zJ‘), representing a magnetic interaction between chains through π-π interactions and hydrogen bonds, was added to account for the actual nature of the complex. The magnetic data were fitted to lead to g = 2.15, J = 0.36 cm-1, zJ‘ = -0.05 cm-1, and R = 1.39 × 10-4 (the R value is defined as ∑[(χM)obs - (χM)calcd]2/∑[(χM)obs]2).

elements.content: χT (K) vs T plots for complex 1. The solid line represents the best theoretical fits.
elements.clean_text: 5  χT (K) vs T plots for complex 1. The solid line represents the best theoretical fits.

elements.content: The positive J value indicates the presence of a ferromagnetic exchange coupling mediated by this kind of unusual oxalate bridge. This can be explained on the basis of Kahn theory. According to Kahn theory, the exchange coupling constant (J) may be expressed as a sum of the negative antiferromagnetic (J AF) and positive ferromagnetic (J F) contribution. In complex 1, the magnetic orbital at copper(II) is defined by the short equatorial bonds, and it is of d x 2 - y 2 type with possibly some mixture of the d z 2 character in the axial position. Two adjacent copper(II) ions are bridged by oxalate through equatorial−axial positions and the copper−copper distance through this kind of bridge is longer, 6.003 Å. Both of them reduce the overlap of the magnetic orbitals, which will result in a reduction of the magnitude of J A F. Therefore, the reduced antiferromagnetic interaction of J A F is taken as evidence of ferromagnetic coupling of J F.
elements.clean_text: The positive J value indicates the presence of a ferromagnetic exchange coupling mediated by this kind of unusual oxalate bridge. This can be explained on the basis of Kahn theory. According to Kahn theory, the exchange coupling constant (J) may be expressed as a sum of the negative antiferromagnetic (J AF) and positive ferromagnetic (J F) contribution. In complex 1, the magnetic orbital at copper(II) is defined by the short equatorial bonds, and it is of d x   2  -  y   2  type with possibly some mixture of the d z   2  character in the axial position. Two adjacent copper(II) ions are bridged by oxalate through equatorial-axial positions and the copper-copper distance through this kind of bridge is longer, 6.003 Å. Both of them reduce the overlap of the magnetic orbitals, which will result in a reduction of the magnitude of J A F. Therefore, the reduced antiferromagnetic interaction of J A F is taken as evidence of ferromagnetic coupling of J F.

elements.content: In conclusion, A novel ferromagnetic 1D chain copper(II) complex has been obtained in which the oxalate bridge is bounded to the two metal centers by unusual modes and cyclic water hexamers extend into one-dimensional tapes. The π−π stacking interactions themselves are weak, but those in complex 1 can induce 2D layer encapsulating water hexamer tapes. The overall structure is stabilized by both water−MOF and water−water interactions. This work provides a good paradigm in crystal engineering to synthesize new compounds with both water tapes and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, A novel ferromagnetic 1D chain copper(II) complex has been obtained in which the oxalate bridge is bounded to the two metal centers by unusual modes and cyclic water hexamers extend into one-dimensional tapes. The π-π stacking interactions themselves are weak, but those in complex 1 can induce 2D layer encapsulating water hexamer tapes. The overall structure is stabilized by both water-MOF and water-water interactions. This work provides a good paradigm in crystal engineering to synthesize new compounds with both water tapes and magnetic properties.

metadata.title:
Extended Tapes of Cyclic Water Hexamers in an Unusual Oxalate-Bridged
One-Dimensional Copper(II) Complex
